text: Painted images of the Elizabethan age -

A world divided by religious hatred. The new Protestant faith is spreading. Bodies burned on a pyre - men writhing under torture - a momentary half-recognisable face, gaunt and staring - FATHER ROBERT RESTON.

The most powerful ruler in Christendom, Philip of Spain, has sworn to return all Europe to the Catholic faith. Images of rival monarchs Philip and Elizabeth in court paintings: stiff, formal, imperious.
Only England stands in his way: a weak impoverished nation ruled by a woman. Finally images of God in judgement, as if speaking to his chosen servant.
Philip prepares to obey the will 2             of his God.
Bn ascetic-looking man dressed in black kneels in a small plain chapel, in virtual darkness. PHILIP II, King of Spa bows his head low, abasing himself before his God.
scorial Palace, Spain, 1585. Now, slowly, he raises his head. His eyes open, and we se there the glow of a new certainty. God has spoken to him.
(I hear. I obey. My Lord and my 1 God.)

3 Philip walks rapidly down a long corridor that opens out into a broader hallway, moving from the darkness of the chapel into ever brighter light and more visible glory. O his face the far shining gaze of a man who now knows his mission. Silent servants press themselves to the walls as he goes by. Through the hallway to a grand salon. COURTIE fall silent and bow as he passes. So into the grandest salon of all, where his magnificent court is gathered; among them his 12-year-old daughter, the INFANTA. As he enters, all kneel. His eyes scan his ministers and courtiers, all kneeling, heads bowed before him. His gaze falls on one who wears t plain black robes of a Jesuit priest: Robert Reston, the face we glimpsed in the opening montage. He speaks to all
(God has made his will known to me. The time for our great enterprise has come.) The Jesuit looks up and his eyes too show a powerful but disciplined satisfaction. He murmurs softly to himself.
At last. Cathedral bells ring out. The cheers of a crowd are heard through the open windows. The king passes out onto the salon's first-floor balcony.

4 Hot sunlight. Philip stands gazing across the plaza at th great cathedral on the far side, as the bells ring out an the CROWD in the plaza below wave their hats and cheer. T Infanta is by his side. His MINISTERS cluster behind him. Lining the crowd on either side of the plaza stand column of ARMED SOLDIERS: a formidable reminder of the king's power. Philip does nothing, but his presence intoxicates the crowd. As their cries swell, wave upon wave, the king's eyes glow and he breathes in deeply, feeding on his people's adoration.
5 A ripple of light on the water. A blur of approaching colour. May 1 Blue Draft--p.3

The ROYAL BARGE is gliding towards us, slowly taking shap its hull gaily painted, its canopy adorned with colourful fabrics, its banks of oars rising and falling, casting bright shards of shining water in the sunlight.

eople passing on the river bank point and wave, smiling, cheering. They see the Queen now. They call out. Two young men walking arm-in-arm stare more intently than any; but they do not cheer or wave. There's something chilling in the way they track the distant figure of the Queen. They are BABINGTON and SAVAGE. Over this an insistent voice:
Why do you go among the people, majesty? I tell you plainly, you will be murdered! Every Catholic in England is a potential assassin! 4

6 An agitated group is gathered in this room where the business of state is transacted. We catch glimpses of the Queen in their midst, preparing to leave, as her minister try to persuade her of the seriousness of the situation: SIR CHRISTOPHER HATTON, 30s, an ambitious courtier; LORD HOWARD, 50s, a weathered old campaigner; and standing bac from the rest, watching from the side lines, SIR FRANCIS WALSINGHAM, the Queen's veteran friend and adviser.
Be warned by the atrocities in France! God-fearing Christians murdered by Papist cut-throats inflamed by hatred of the truth!

We know the Catholics take their                          orders from Spain. The Spanish                            speak openly of Mary Stuart as                            Queen of England in waiting.
(sharply)
Mary Stuart is a Queen cast out by her own ungrateful nation.

With respect, majesty - a                                 Catholic Queen. Your loyal Protestant supporters don't                               understand why Mary Stuart lives                          under our protection, at our expense - very considerable                               expense -
Mary Stuart is my cousin. She is                          our guest. And she is under our                           control.
But while she lives, majesty, she                         is a beacon that draws our                                enemies' eyes and hopes.
While she lives?
She is the poison at the heart of                         England. The poison must be cut                           out.                                                      4A
You'd have me make a martyr of                            her. What is her crime?
7 The Londoners on the river bank cheer and wave as the roy barge goes by.
Treachery, ma'am. All Catholics                           are traitors! Their loyalty is to                         the Pope of Rome.
How many Catholics are there in England, sir?
Immense numbers, majesty!
We believe half the nation clings                         to the old superstitions.                                 5
What would you have me do? `Cut                           out' half the people of England?
We must act, majesty. Our                                 inaction is taken to be weakness.
If any of my people break the                             law, they will be punished. Until that day, I wish them to be let                           them alone.
Until the day they rise in                                rebellion! Majesty, we have proven reason to fear every Catholic in the land -
Fear creates fear, sir. I will not punish my people for their beliefs. Only for their deeds. am assured that the people of England love their Queen. My constant endeavour is to earn that love.

9 Londoners on the river banks wave and cheer. Elizabeth, seated on the royal barge, sees them with satisfaction. S gives an occasional slight inclination of her head in acknowledgement. Elizabeth sits with her favourite seated beside her, her youngest and prettiest maid of honour, BESS THROCKMORTON. Walsingham sits facing them, looking sourly at the cheeri spectators.
The people are agitated.
What people?
Your bishops are preaching that                    God is showing his displeasure-                    the Queen being still unmarried -                  some are saying infertile -
What nonsense!
Dangerous nonsense. Mary Stuart                    has a son -
Why does everyone torment me with                  Mary Stuart? Pink Revision May 18- p.6 ELIZABETH(cont'd)

It's not her fault that she's                       next in line to the throne.                         (to Bess)                                       Don't hide your face. She leans over to brush a stray lock of hair from Bess's face.
So long as you have no issue.                       Elizabeth looks back at Wsalsingham.
Produce an heir and there'll be                     no more talk of Mary Stuart.
Isn't it customary to obtain a                      husband before producing an heir? (to Bess)                                       We shall have to look out a husband for you soon, Bess.
Not too soon, my lady.
There are husbands to be had.
(to Bess)                                       Don't you want to be married?
I'll want the marriage if I want the man.
Austria. France. Sweden.
Why stop there? Turkey has a                        Sultan. China has an Emperor.                       (to Bess)                                       What sort of man do you want?
I confine myself to the possible.
An honest man. With friendly                        eyes.
(to Walsingham)
That's where you and I differ,                            Walsingham. I find the impossible                         far more interesting.                                     (to Bess)
And good legs. You'll want good legs.
And sweet breath.
So that you can kiss him without choking. (to Walsingham)
There must be any amount of                               princes in undiscovered lands                             across the sea. Find me an honest one of those.
The royal party enters the Cathedral. Elizabeth and Walsingham advance into the wide empty nave, followed by the Queen's ladies and the guards. Bess is now back in he place among the ladies.
Ship builders are being recruited in Spanish ports at double wages. The sea wall at Dover is cracking. There's no money to rebuild our defences. I don't need advisers to tell me my business.
They care for your safety, majesty. The threats to your person are real.

And they know very well that if I fall, they all come tumbling down after me. She goes on to the steps at the foot of the altar, and kneels to pray. As she kneels she holds out one hand behi her, not looking round. Bess steps forward, and taking he hand, kneels and prays with her. Double Pink revision 18 July - p.8
Let's pray, Bess. May we have wisdom not to fear shadows in the night, and courage when the day of danger truly dawns. ON ELIZABETH as she prays.
10 Double Pink revision 18 July - p.9

11 Raleigh is standing on the prow of a war-ship as it cuts through the water toward the white cliffs of Dover. The ship and its sailors have been at sea for many months, an it shows. Raleigh shouts to his Sailing-Master.
Let England know we're back, Mr                           Calley.
Master Gunner, run out starboard and tie-off. A broadside from the                         bow.
Run out and prime. From the bow                           number one gun, on my word -                              discharge! Two -- Three-- Four. Canon fire echoes over the distant white cliffs.
13 ON ELIZABETH - Imperfectly reflected in a mirror in the soft candlelight. Her ladies are putting her clothes away
Bess begins the process of stripping away her make-up. lizabeth studies her true face as it comes into view.
Lines round my mouth. Where did they come from?
Smile lines, my lady.
Smile lines? When do I smile?                             With that she smiles, and sees Bess's answering reflected smile.
Now you have smile lines too.
May 1 Blue Draft - p.10
Her smile fades. She gazes at her now naked face, vulnerable in the mirror.
The royal bed, immense and ornate. Elizabeth lies here small, awake, and alone.
`Elizabeth! The angels weep for you, Elizabeth! Why do you close                          your ears to the voice of your                            loving God?'
Foresters at work felling great trees, working rhythmically, in pairs. From all round echoes the same sound, of axe on timber.

`Elizabeth! You are leading the souls of your people to Hell! Turn back! Marry me, and save England!'I spoke to her just as I speak to you now. ow we see the royal carriage riding through mature forest accompanied by a mounted entourage. IN THE CARRIAGE - The king, Philip II, the Infanta and Father Robert Reston.
But she did not listen. She made me a speech about the virtues of virginity. Me! Virginity! She has brought this on herself.
hilip surveys the scene through the carriage window with shudder.

Every tree that falls hurts me. I lose a part of myself. I am cursed with sensitivity. I feel too much. We don't yet know what the felling of the trees portends. But Reston does. To him, it's a glorious sight.
Your majesty has a merciful soul. May 1 Blue Draft - p.11

I sacrifice my country's forests to save the souls of a lost nation. That is true mercy. England is lost to darkness, Father. I bring light. WIDE NOW - We see the carriage and the royal party crest hill, and there is revealed an awesome sight: the forest has been felled as far as the eye can see. Great piles of cut timber dot the ravaged landscape. Everywhere men are work lopping branches from felled trees. Wagon teams haul immense trunks away. Fires burn stacks of lopped branches and the smoke rises up into the empty sky.
N THE CARRIAGE - On Reston's face as he stares at the fires. He speaks half to himself, out of the depths of hi own fanatical certainty.
The light of purifying fire. He turns and fixes the king with his intent gaze.
My time has come, majesty. (Beat)
Send me home.
Establishing wide shot of chartley Hall.
14 A small yapping Skye terrier is barking at a LAUNDRESS, w is handing over a letter, folded small, to a sharp-faced middle-aged French lady's maid, ANNETTE. The laundress curtseys and leaves.

15 The terrier scampers ahead of Annette to its mistress, MA STUART, who sits embroidering a pink satin petticoat. She is a handsome but bitter woman in her mid-thirties. Round her stands her small retinue of three ladies and a chaplain.
This is so pretty I'm inclined to send it as a present to my dear cousin Elizabeth. She holds up the delicate work to show her ladies. May 1 Blue Draft - p.12

It is an intimate garment, of                         course. But even Elizabeth must                       have the occasional intimate                          moment.                                               Annette reaches her mistress and kneels before her, holdi out the letter.
My Queen. Mary lays down her needlework and takes the letter from h and reads it for herself.
Our friends write to give us hope.
(low) Soon England's true believers will rise up against the bastard usurper Elizabeth, and slit her throat, and throw her down to hell.
That's enough, Annette. (But she loves it.) Slit her throat? Please.

And when the bastard usurper is dead, my lady will be queen. The chaplain gives a sharp cough of warning. The Warden of Chartley Hall, SIR AMYAS PAULET, enters the room. He is soberly dressed, but has charming manners, an is clearly susceptible to his handsome ward. Mary turns t him at once with a teasing smile.
Here's my noble jailer, come to                       smack my hand.                                        She holds out one hand to be smacked. The other hand hold the letter out of sight.
Have I sinned again, sir?
No, no, my lady. Unless beauty is                     counted a sin.                                        DoubleGoldenrod - 25 July -p.13 PAULET(cont'd)
(Kissing her hand)                             I come to pay my respects.
Oh, you jailer. I don't trust                      you.

Not jailer, my lady, please.                       Warden. Protector. Friend. You                     are the Queen's guest.                             Mary signs to her ladies. One of them brings her the embroidery, discreetly receiving in exchange the hidden letter.
See how I pass my time in my                       lonely prison.

Charming, ma'am. Distractingly                     charming.                                          She holds the intimate garment against her body. Paulet seems to be too fascinated by it to notice he is being duped.
Such a pretty undergarment. But for whose eyes?                                    DoubleGoldenrod - 25 July -p.14
17 A pistol is being loaded: a fiddly process involving a powder horn, wadding, and an iron ball the size of a hazelnut.
So what's it for, my young                               friend? Not for shooting rabbits,                        I'm guessing.
We live in dangerous times.
We do indeed. Savage moves close as if to study the loading process. We see the two of them talking from outside the window.
(very low)

The conspiracy gains strength.                           Tell our master one of the circle has already gained access to the                         court.                                                   The Armourer nods. He hands the pistol to Savage. Savage takes it and leaves. Immediately after, a man enters and walks up behind the n seated Armourer. The Armourer turns round.
I ask for your forgiveness.                              Moving with speed, he seizes the Armourer's head, twists to one side, and snaps his neck. Reston walks quietly out of the store.

18 A crowd of eager SPECTATORS and WOULD-BE COURTIERS has gathered, held back by a line of guards, all hoping to attract the attention of the Queen when she appears. This is the route from the Presence Chamber to the Chapel Roya May 1 Blue Draft - p.15

Every Sunday the Queen processes here, and crowds gather see her. Two of Walsingham's men, AGENTS 1 and 2, mingle the crowd: faces we'll see again. Tom Babington stands unobtrusively at the back of the crowd. He carries a bag which may or may not contain a gu

bustle of activity, a ripple of anticipation - `She's coming!' - and the palace doors open. BABINGTON'S POV: the crowd, the wall of BODYGUARDS, the cluster of COURTIERS and LADIES, and in their midst, Elizabeth, almost completely masked as she passes by. Alongside the Queen, among her maids-of-honour, is Bess Throckmorton; behind her, Walsingham. The people cheer, call out to the Queen, reach to touch her, fall to their knees.
God bless your majesty - God love you! - See her sweet face! Others in the crowd are shouting more militant sentiments

Hang the Papists! - Look out for traitors, Elizabeth! Mary Stuart                       is the whore of Rome!                                  Babington moves forward, easing his way to the front of t crowd. Nearby there stands another young man who is watching, not cheering: RAMSAY. A WOMAN WTH A BABY pushes her way almost to the Queen, holding her baby before her.

Your blessing, majesty. My little one, your blessing.                                    BABINGTON'S POV- The Queen stopping to bless the little baby, smiling, putting out her hand to touch the baby's head. The mother bobs a curtsey. The Queen moves on, with her entourage. A sudden scuffle in the crowd. Babington turns to look. A CLOAK SWEEPS THROUGH FRAME - dropping down to the groun revealing as it passes the handsome smiling face of Raleigh, directly in R the path of the Queen.

A puddle in the way, majesty. Elizabeth signs to the guards to stay calm. She stares at Raleigh, then she looks down at the cloak. No sign of any puddles. Bess Throckmorton watches, suppressing a smile.
Elizabeth looks back up, meets Raleigh's eyes with a cool appraising gaze. Then she walks on over the cloak, shakin her head.

A puddle... The guards take up their positions once more. Bess throws Raleigh a quick smile as she follows the royal party. His answering shrug says: I tried. He picks up the cloak, and stands gazing after the Queen. lizabeth goes into the chapel, and the doors close behind her.
The Queen is at her prayers!
The Queen at her prayers, her mind elsewhere; privately amused.
A puddle...
Raleigh puts an arm round Calley.
She spoke to me. You have to give me that.
Oh, I do. The Queen spoke to you. One word - but she spoke.
Two words.
You're made. A dukedom at the very least.
Did you see the girl behind her? I've been at sea too long.
19 The Great Hall is crowded with competing factions. A grou of Spaniards, led by their Ambassador, DON GUERAU DE SPES stand watching everyone else with haughty disdain.
Yellow Revision May 22--p.17

An architect waits to present details of a building project. Petitioners wait vainly, in the hope of catching the Queen's eye. Howard and Hatton are in attendance. Walsingham stands by the Queen's side, briefing her in a low murmur for her ears only.

Thousands are dying every day of                    famine in Ireland. Another                          rebellion is a distinct                             possibility.                                        A courtier is holding a portrait which he shows to the Queen.
Francis of Valois, majesty.
Brother to the king of France, majesty.
France is in religious turmoil. It would be unwise to engage with                   their instability.
(to Lord Howard)                                You have the plans for the new docks?
Here, majesty. Howard beckons the Architect forward to show his model. Elizabeth studies it. Walsingham murmurs on.
We still need to keep France out                    of the arms of Spain.
Let me think on it.                                 (to Howard)                                     What if enemy ships should sail up the Thames? Can the docks be closed?
Not closed, majesty. But the gun                    positions here, and here, have                      full command of the channel.                        The courtier displays a second portrait.
King Erik of Sweden, majesty.                       Yellow Revision May 22--p.17A
What again?
Still madly in love with you.
Still mad, you mean. (Looking                      around). Where's Bess?                             The courtier presents a third portrait.
Ivan, Tsar of all the Russias,                     known as "The Terrible."                           Walsingham merely shakes his head. Buff revision 6th June- p.18

20 Bess Throckmorton is late. She comes running through the crowd of lesser petitioners who wait in the hope of gaini access to the Queen. She passes Calley, the two native Americans, and a group of sailors holding large hampers. Raleigh is trying to persuade the doorkeeper to let him past.

You'll have to see the Lord                             Chamberlain, sir.                                       He indicates a portly man surrounded by petitioners, beyo the open doors to the inner rooms.
How am I to see him if you won't let me through?
You must wait for him to come out, sir.
And when will he come out?

There's no way of knowing that,                         sir.                                                    The doorkeeper stands aside for Bess. She recognises Raleigh, and throws him a smile before rushing past.
(as if to Calley)
I had less trouble than this boarding a Spanish ship!                                Everything is easier when you can                       kill people.
21 Bess curtseys before Elizabeth; who shakes her head at he
Late again, Bess.
I beg your majesty's forgiveness.
Given. Once. Buff revision 6th June- p.18A
The puddle man is outside, majesty.
Yellow Revision May 22-- p.19
Elizabeth takes Bess's arm and turns with her to the portraits.
My suitors. The Courtier has a fourth portrait.
The Archduke Charles of Austria,                   majesty.
The younger brother of Maximilian II, the Holy Roman Emperor.
A cousin of Philip II of Spain.
He's rather sweet.
More your age than mine, Bess. How old is he?
Young... I believe, majesty. An                    Austrian alliance would keep France quiet.
And it would put Philip on a                       leash.                                             Elizabeth looks across at the Spaniards.
I become almost enthusiastic. to Hatton)                                    Send for him. (to Bess) Where is he, then? Bess understands. She bobs and hurries to the door.
(to Walsingham) How much longer do you think I can play this game?
Virginity is an asset that holds its value well.
Diplomatically speaking. Yellow Revision May 22 - p.19A
Raleigh now enters with Calley, the native Americans and court servants carrying hampers.
Yellow Revision May 22 - p.20
One of the Spaniards recognises him and murmurs to the Ambassador; who speaks angrily to the Queen.
Majesty, this man is a notorious pirate.
Indeed? Don Guerau points to the hampers.
Spanish treasure, stolen from Spanish ships. You will see.
aleigh kneels before the Queen. Elizabeth gestures for hi to rise.
Well, sir. Who are you?
Walter Raleigh, your majesty.
Ah, yes. Raleigh. I've heard of your voyage. What's your rank?
A gentleman of Devon.
What do you want?
The honour to be in the presence of my Queen, whose radiant beauty is the boast and glory of the English people.
Yes, well, here you are.
I'm just returned from the New World, majesty. I have claimed the fertile coast in your name, and called it Virginia, in honour of our Virgin Queen. Elizabeth raises her eyebrows.
Virginia? And if I marry? Will you change the name to Conjugia? A royal joke. Her entourage laughs dutifully.
Yellow Revision May 22 -p.21
I ask for your gracious permission, majesty, to return to the New World with your royal warrant, to found a colony under the laws and protections of England.
lizabeth's eye has fallen on the native Americans.
Who are they?
Americans, majesty. They long to                      be your newest subjects. He beckons Calley to lead Wanchese and Manteo forward.
Have they no ruler of their own?

None to match England's Queen. Elizabeth gazes at the natives. She holds out her hand. Unaware that he's meant to kiss the Queen's hand, Manteo, takes it and shakes it. A gasp from the watching courtier But Elizabeth accepts the courtesy.
These gentlemen are welcome. See that they're treated well. Calley hurries them away before worse happens.
I also come bearing gifts for your majesty, from the New World. He beckons to the servants to bring the baskets. Don Guer steps forward.
The fruits of piracy, majesty. The true property of the realm of Spain.
Let's see, shall we? to Raleigh) What do you bring me?
Mud, and leaves.
May 1 Blue Draft - p.22
Members of the court share suppressed smiles.
(amused) Mud and leaves? aleigh throws open the first basket. Don Guerau peers inside suspiciously. It does indeed seem to be filled wit mud. Raleigh takes out a potato beneath the Ambassador's nose.
Patata, majesty. You eat it. Very nourishing. He beckons forward the second basket, which is full of leaves. Again Don Guerau tracks his every move. He takes out a tobacco leaf. R
Tobacco. You breathe its smoke. Very stimulating. Now Don Guerau realises he's being laughed at on all side He draws himself up with angry pride, wrinkling his nose.
Forgive me, majesty, I find the air has become stale. I am sensitive to the smell of open sewers. A glare at Raleigh, a bow for the Queen, and Don Guerau leads his Spaniards out.
(to Raleigh) Continue. With a broad smile, Raleigh gestures forward the third basket. This one really is full of gold. He takes out a gold coin and presents it to Elizabeth.
Gold. You spend it. Very satisfying. Elizabeth examines the fat gold coin, with its image of Philip of Spain. She tries not to smile.
Courtesy of a Spanish ship, that found itself unable to complete its journey. Elizabeth drops the gold coin back into the basket. Green Revision May 25 - p.23
The fruits of piracy after all,                           it seems.
Philip of Spain is no friend of England, majesty. The more gold I take from him, the safer you will be.
Well, well. A political pirate. A logic-chopping pirate.
And your majesty's most loyal subject. She gives him a long look.
But not my best dressed. W    (Beat) elcome home, Mr Raleigh. She turns her attention back to Hatton and the portraits. Raleigh bows and withdraws, followed by his men. Walsingh follows.
22 Raleigh comes out into the hallway with Calley by his sid
What did you think of her?
Terrifying.

But magnificent.                                          He moves on. Raleigh's eyes fall on Don Guerau, the Spanish Ambassador passing near with his fellow Spaniards and a few English courtiers and ministers, including Hatton. Don Guerau stares at him. The doors to the privy chamber open and the Queen's ladie come swishing out in a tight chattering group, Bess besid her friend MARGARET. May 1 Blue Draft - p.24
`Mud and leaves'! I nearly died!
`Patata! You eat it!' They giggle as they go by.
She liked him. I could tell.
Well, wouldn't you? They see Raleigh now, and the chatter ceases. The ladies come to a stop and curtsey. Raleigh gives a bow, his eyes singling out Bess.
I'm glad to have the opportunity to thank you. Without your help, I'd still be in outer darkness.
I did very little, sir. You'd already caught the Queen's eye.

Then I thank you for the very little. The ladies go on their way and the laughing chatter resumes, with many a backward glance at the handsome Raleigh. No one pays attention to a figure in the shadows another of Walsingham's men, AGENT 3. 23
Young Savage stands alone among trees, shivering, white- faced, half-mumbling, half-singing an endless prayer. He holds a pistol with which he means to kill himself. But h can't do it.         S
(singing)

Salve regina, mater misericordiae, vita dulcedo et spes nostra salve... In a clearing nearby three men sit round a fire. They are young Catholic fanatics - Babington, Ramsay, and FRANCIS THROCKMORTON. A fourth man stands before them, his back t us, watching Savage. At first we don't see who he is. May 1 Blue Draft - p.25

His weakness endangers us all. He can't go on with us. And we can't leave him behind. Now the man turns and looks intently at Babington, and we see he is Robert Reston; no longer in the clothes of a priest.
Who will help him? Babington rises. Reston nods his approval. Babington goes off through the trees. Reston and the others follow a little behind.

singing) Ad te clamamus, exsulaes filii Evae. Ad te suspiramus gementes et flentes in hac lacrimarum valle - He sings on as Babington approaches him, seeming no longe to know what's happening. Babington takes the pistol from his hand.
Make your peace with God. Savage stares, and suddenly realises what Babington means to do. Terror overwhelms him.
No, Tom! Don't kill me! I don't want to die! Now he's blubbering with fear. Babington is shaken by thi and can't shoot. Reston begins to pray aloud.
Si ambulam in medio umbrae mortis, non timebo mala - The others join in with the words of the well-known psalm Babington too joins in, now weeping.
Quoniam tu mecum es, Domine. Virga tua et baculus tuus, ipsa me consolata sunt -
ANG! Savage falls dead.
May 1 Blue Draft - p.26
24 Walsingham enters his private home, and gives his hat and cloak to his servant.

Visitor waiting, sir. Walsingham frowns. He climbs the stairs to the door of hi study. There, pacing nervously, is his younger brother WILLIAM, a middle-aged student. Walsingham's scowl disappears. He opens his arms wide.
William!
Hello, Francis. They embrace. Then Walsingham pushes him back to take a good look at him.
You look terrible. Don't they feed you in Paris? How are your studies? Learned the secrets of the universe yet?
Not yet.
These are dangerous times to be questioning the ways of God. You must take care of yourself.
My needs are simple.
You'll dine with us? You'll lodge with us? is daughter MARY appears at the top of the next flight.
William! She comes tumbling down and into his arms. She's an eager innocent 20-year-old, much loved by her father.
Look at you! All grown up. URSULA, Walsingham's wife, appears as Mary leads William the stairs.
May 1 Blue Draft - p.27
William. This is a pleasure.
I've been away too long, ma'am.
You come with me, William. ary and William go on into the family's living rooms. Ursula meets her husband's eyes.
He's not still a student, is he?
26 William is by the fire, listening to Mary playing the virginal and singing. Walsingham and Ursula are by the dinner table.
Have you spoken to the Queen?
I speak to her daily.
You know what I mean. You've done enough. No man could do more.
I can't leave court yet. The Queen needs me.
So you're to die in harness like a pack horse, are you? And for what? (calling)
Mary! William!
These are difficult times-
It's always difficult times.                             Mary joins them, her arm in William's. Walsingham seizes the opportunity to change the subject.

William, come and tell us all the                        new ideas in the University. Will                        the great breach in the church                           ever be healed?                                          May 1 Blue Draft - p.28
I doubt it, brother. Compromise                    is out of fashion. On both sides                   they say there can only be one                     truth, and one God.
Sit, sit.
ere by me, William.
What do they say in Paris of the                   Pope's call for holy war?
Many welcome it.
I don't understand why we must all hate each other.
Truth will always hate falsehood, ma'am.
Why do we have to talk about war? Tell us your nice news, William. Are you married yet?
(smiling) Not yet.
Then we must find you a nice sensible English wife.
No, no. I won't be staying long. I must go back to my studies.
Not too soon, I hope. Every man deserves a rest.

Listen to him! When did you last rest, I'd like to know? (to William) He won't listen to me. Not a thought for his health. You tell him, he's your brother. He'll die at his desk, out of sheer selfishness.
Green Revision May 25 - p.29
Walsingham shares a rueful smile with William that says, `Women, eh?'. They take their seats for dinner. 2

7 Elizabeth sits sumptuously gowned and jewelled at an ornately-dressed dining table, surrounded by her ladies, Bess among them; Walsingham discreetly in the background. I'm - Her hand touches her waist.
You're pregnant?

No one knows. My plans are made. I shall ask the Queen for permission to leave court. I shall live quietly in the country with - with my child. The Queen must know nothing. Raleigh stares at her, stunned. More people are passing. This is no place for R displays of strong feeling.
Where will you go?
To my mother's house.
You can't go!
I'm a ward of the Queen. I can't court a man without her permission. I can't marry without her permission. As for having a child - Another official passes by.
When were you planning to leave?
As soon as I'm allowed. Raleigh finds himself caught in an impossible situation. His internal struggle shows itself in the twists and jerk of his body.
Am I not to see you again? What's to become of the child? Bess -
may 1 blue draft 28 June - p. 88
Hush! We've no choice. You know it as well as I do.
All I know is nothing's as it should be.
Please listen. You once said to me, `Whatever I have to give, ask and it's yours.' Do you remember?
Of course I remember.
I ask that you forget me. Go to your ship. Do your duty. Forget me.
aleigh gazes at her, deeply moved.
Oh, Bess... The Queen's ladies come hurrying by. Margaret calls to Be as they go.
Bess! We're summoned.
I'm coming. (to Raleigh)
Goodbye. She runs after the ladies. Raleigh walks slowly after them down the hall. On his fac a new look forms. He knows now what he's going to do.
103 An empty horizon. Then, on the very line of the horizon, the ghost of a movement. Far away, too small to make out, something is coming. 1 may 1 blue draft 28 June - p. 89
104 Elizabeth starts up in bed, calls out in sudden fear.
Air! I must have air! Her servants hurry in, and open the window. Elizabeth goes to the open window and breathes in deeply. She looks up at the moon.
With this ring I thee wed. With my body I thee worship... 05
Raleigh and Bess are being married in secret by a PRIEST. The only witness is Bess's fellow maid of honour Margaret Raleigh makes his vow tenderly and lovingly, his eyes on Bess throughout.
... and with all my worldly goods H         I thee endow. e places the ring on her left thumb.
In the name of the father - He moves the ring to her forefinger -
And of the Son - To her index finger -
And of the Holy Spirit. And finally onto her ring finger.
Amen.
106 A room in which a map of Europe is inlaid in the floor. A table strewn with maps stands in the centre. Elizabeth is imperious, back in control.
Grey Revisions 22 June -p.90
This Spanish Armada is at sea carrying an army of ten thousand men. (indicating on the map)
The Duke of Parma has fifteen thousand men on the French coast.
They plan to cross the Channel in barges, under the protection of the Spanish fleet, and sail up the Thames.
But they don't yet have enough barges at Calais. We have a little time.
(surprised)
That is so.
Our forces defend the Thames entrance at Tilbury. How many men?
We have three, possibly four thousand, majesty.
If the Spanish fleet reaches Calais in strength, the combined armies will be beyond our power to resist.
Therefore, the Spanish fleet must not reach Calais.
Majesty, this vast Armada will surely smash through our naval defences. We must be prepared for the worst.
lizabeth walks briskly through the great public rooms bac to her quarters, with Walsingham by her side and her entourage following behind.
How did you know about the numbers of the Dutch barges, majesty? I don't recall supplying you with that information.

You may observe, Walsingham, that I don't see my way with only one eye. Nor do I hop along on only one leg. Why then would I rely on only one source of information? She sweeps into her quarters. Her ladies, waiting there, jump up in haste. She scans them.
Where's Bess? Her eyes coem to rest on Margaret. She sees that Margaret knows something.
Where is she?

108 We are on the very tip of England. A watch-tower has been built, and next to it a large beac of wood. A YOUNG MAN is minding the watch. He stares out to sea, catching sight of something. Over t rim of the world has appeared the long line of the Spanis fleet, like a floating wall, black and menacing.

e runs down the steps from the tower. He lights a bundle of sticks and thrusts them again and again into the beaco The beacon catches fire. As the flames rise into the sky, so a second beacon erupts into flame on the next headland And then a third on the next, a fourth on the next, a fifth, disappearing around the coastline.
109 Doors burst open and Elizabeth comes storming out, barely containing a powerful rage.
Bess! Bess Throckmorton! Bess comes running from the far end. May 1 Blue Draft -p.92
Here, my lady!

Tell me! Is it true? Are you                          married? Are you with child? Are                      you WITH CHILD?                                       Bess stands before her with her head bowed.

Yes, my lady.                                         Elizabeth falls on her with uncontrolled rage, striking o at her, beating her about the head, shrieking out the wor that so inflame and wound her. Bess takes the blows in silence.

You traitress! You dare to have                       secrets from me! I am your Queen!                     You ask my permission before you rut - before you marry - before you breed! My bitches wear my collars! Do you hear me? How dare you be with child! Walsingham comes hobbling up.
Majesty, please! Dignity - mercy - But Elizabeth is too far gone. She turns on him, eyes blazing.
This is no time for mercy! That's what you said to me. I don't forget. But you showed mercy, Walsingham! Go to your traitor brother, and leave me to my business!
alsingham turns white. Elizabeth is back berating Bess.
Is it his child? Tell me! Say it! Is the child his? Tell me! Say it! Is it his? Bess responds to the Queen's hysteria with dignity.
Yes, my lady. It is - my husband's child. Her gaze reaches beyond the Queen. Elizabeth turns.
May 1 Blue Draft -p.93
Raleigh has come up to them unnoticed. He has seen and heard all. He speaks to Elizabeth quietly, sadly.

This is not the Queen I love and serve. Elizabeth stares at him. He meets her eyes. His gaze is s unflinching that slowly the madness drains out of her. Wh she speaks next, she is her proud self again.
This gentleman has seduced a lady                         under my care. This lady has                              married without my consent. These are offences punishable by law. (to Walsingham)
Arrest him.

111 rom way up high we see beacon after warning beacon bursting into flame, the light from them describing the contours of England. As they rush on, they suddenly divide, some continuing along the coast, others racing inland.
Dr Dee watches as Elizabeth prowls his cluttered rooms, releasing the tension that has swelled to bursting point within her.
The fall of an empire, you told me. Did you mean the English empire? Because by God, England will not fall while I am Queen! If that's your prophecy, sir, prophesy again!
You want me to tell your majesty only what your majesty chooses to hear?
May 1 Blue Draft -p.94
I will not be a toy of the fates! Have I not faced an assassin's bullet and lived? She turns to Dr Dee and sees his quizzical gaze on her, a she lets her rage pass.
Just tell me there's no certainty. The shadows of ghosts, you said. Any outcome is possible. Give me hope.

The forces that shape the world are greater than all of us, majesty. How can I promise you that they'll conspire in your favour, even though you are the Queen? But this much I know. When the storm breaks, each man acts in accordance with his own nature. Some are dumb with terror. Some flee. Some hide. And some spread their wings like eagles and soar on the wind. Elizabeth understands. She draws herself up, finding now the self-belief she needs for the battle to come.
You're a wise man, Dr Dee.
And you, madam, are a very great lady.
lizabeth stares out of the window, watches as the last beacon is kindled not far away, and bursts into flame. Behind her stand her ministers: Hatton, Howard, and Walsingham.
he turns to face the others. All littleness has dropped away. She sees only her nation's hour of destiny, and her own duty.
My lords, I can offer you no                              words of comfort.                                         DoubleGoldenrod - 25 July -p.95 ELIZABETH(cont'd)
If this Armada succeeds there                            will be no more freedom in our land, and England will be no more. We cannot be defeated.
113 The unending line of Spanish ships advances over the wate Still far away, but scary in power and reach.
What news? Is the fleet at sea?
Yes, sir. May God preserve them.

114 Raleigh lies awake and fully dressed on the bed in his prison room. The room is furnished for a gentleman, but t walls are thick and the windows barred. The door opens, and a servant brings in a tray of food. Raleigh sits up.
What news?
The Spanish are off Portland.
And the fleet?
Still at Plymouth, joined by Drake and all the rest.
(bitter)
All but me.

115 The white cliffs of England, seen from the Channel. INTO FRAME sweeps a SPANISH ENSIGN, streaming from a mast And another, and another. Mast after mast, straining sail shivering ropes, and the FLAGS of the enemy - flying from the top-gallants of a hundred ships - so near to England now that they seem to have been planted already on England's white cliffs. DoubleGoldenrod - 25 July -p.95A

116 The Queen, Sir Christopher Hatton, Walsingham and her entourage, all now heavily armed, enter the great vaulted nave of St Paul's. As they make their way towards the altar, Elizabeth issues commands.
The bells are to ring in every church in the land. Hatton bows to show he has received the order.

Labourers are to leave the fields and take up arms. The harvest must wait. Hatton bows and leaves. Elizabeth continues up the nave, now followed only by Walsingham. She turns to him with another order.
Release all prisoners. England is their country too. She moves forward again. Walsingham follows, waiting, knowing there's more. Elizabeth turns to him one last tim
Release Raleigh. He is forgiven... As I too pray to be forgiven... Walsingham leaves. Elizabeth goes forward to stand before the altar alone.

Leave me. All of you. The remainder of her entourage bow and withdraw. Elizabet goes on down the nave to the altar, and there, at the foo of the steps, sinks to her knees. She does not bow her head. ON ELIZABETH - Alone in the great space, staring at her G
as at an equal. AN UP to the blazing coloured light of the stained glass window - 117
DOWN from high windows to see monks praying for the succe of the Armada. Their chant has a driving war-like rhythm, that carries over the following scenes.
118 SPEED TRACK down a palace corridor, urged on by the beat the chant, into Philip's cell. TRACK IN to the flame of a single candle: its bright hear seems to be the source of the pounding chant.
119 The chant powers on. SHIPS' BOWS slice the water, racing towards us. DoubleGoldenrod - 25 July -p.97
120 ON PHILIP as the chant drives on, murmuring his own praye
Tu es Deus qui facis mirabilia solus. Notam fecisti in gentibus virtutem tuam...
CLOSE ON RALEIGH - A Royal Official has just handed him a letter. He reads it and then looks up.
Tell the Queen I will join my ship.
121 The chant continues - TRACKING THROUGH English troops to the Queen's tent -
The English fleet sets sail and leaves Plymouth harbour.
122 The Queen's advisers mill round Elizabeth. Walsingham is seated in the background.
Are our ships at sea? Has the fleet left Plymouth? That can't be so hard to know. ADMIRAL WINTER enters, out of breath, clutching the lates reports.
The enemy has been engaged, majesty. He reads as he speaks. The news is not so good after all.
A brave action. Two ships lost.
With what gain? DoubleGoldenrod - 25 July -p.97A
The enemy continues to advance.

123 FOREGROUND - Floating wreckage, and the bodies of English sailors. Beyond, the long line of the Spanish fleet, advancing, firing. The Spanish ships are monsters, much taller than the English ships.
Double Pink revision 18 July- p.98

124 Lord Howard bent over a mass of charts with his commander round him: HAWKINS, DRAKE, FROBISHER and Raleigh. The boo of Spanish cannon shakes the air. Flashes of fire light t faces of the English officers.
We must attack! What choice do we have?
We're decisively outgunned, Drake. We are losing too many                            ships. We must defend the coast.
(studying the chart of the Armada's progress)
There has to be a way of getting                         inside this crescent formation.
Our ships may be smaller but they're nimbler. We should use the strengths we've got.
I tell you, we're out-gunned. Do you want to lose the whole fleet?
Break their formation and we have                        a chance.
We can't get near them.
125 Elizabeth among her advisers. An air of mounting panic.
The Spanish are barely a day away, majesty.
t would be wise to withdraw to safer ground. Grey Revision 22 June - p.99
I beg you to appreciate the gravity of the situation, majesty. There is very little time. Elizabeth turns on him, calm and defiant.
Then we must act.

126 A low distant beat as we TRACK THROUGH the English camp. The soldiers are a citizen army, no hardened professional We pass a troop busy sharpening their pikes; an older soldier in quiet prayer; a band sharing drinks; a youth rubbing down a horse. Now they hear the distant beat approaching. One by one th look up, surprised, uncertain. Now they hear it loud and clear: the beat of an army on t march. CLOSE ON tramping feet. An advancing force. Horses' hoove beating the ground.
N THE SOLDIERS' FACES - Staring, half afraid, half expectant - then filled with a surge of sudden hope - SOLDIERS' POV - English flags rising over the low brow of the hill.

127 In the midst of the advancing array of banners and flags, riding a white horse, dressed in silver armour, holding a silver staff - Elizabeth - transformed into a goddess of war. The thousands of gaping soldiers sink awe-struck to their knees. ON ELIZABETH as she surveys her rag-tag army. The army le out a cheer. The Queen cries out to ore) army, her voice echoing in th (m her
chill air.
My loving people! We see the sails of the enemy approaching. We hear the Spanish guns over the water.
Goldenrod revision 1 June - p.100 ELIZABETH(cont'd)

Soon now we will meet them face                           to face. In that encounter,                               England lives, or England dies. I                         am resolved in the midst and heat                         of the battle to live or die                              amongst you all!                                          A cheer from the men.
While we stand together no invader shall pass. Let them come with all the armies of Hell, they will not pass.                                            The crowd gives another mighty cheer.

So let us sound the advance and go forward, together, you and I. I myself will be your general,                            judge and rewarder of every one                           of your virtues in the field.                             When this day of battle is ended, we meet again in heaven, or on the field of victory. he greatest shout of all.
Aye!
128 Dr Dee studies his charts. 129
Philip sits staring at the flame of the candle. The whole world waits.
130 A ship's lamp sways in the window. A sailor notes the movement. DoubleGreen Revision - 22 July - p.101
Wind change! High in the rigging above, a sail flaps and bellies in a new direction. The sound of a rising storm.
131 Elizabeth looks around her as the tent shudders in the rising wind.
132 The vast Armada is being buffeted by the storm, but still it comes on. The sea is in turmoil, lightning streaks across the darkening sky.
(Drop Anchor!)
(Our orders are to stay in                                formation.)
(If we don't drop anchor, we'll                           be smashed on the rocks!) 133
Spanish sailors furl the sails, haul in ropes. An anchor crashes into the sea.
134 Raleigh and Drake hurry along the deck in the whipping wi and spray. Drake is watching the Spanish fleet, and shouting above the noise of the storm.
They've dropped anchor. These                             Spanish monsters can't handle our                         English seas.
We have the wind in our favour.                           Do we go?
We go.                                                    DoubleYellow - 22 July- p.101A
Drake embraces Raleigh. Action at last.
God speed, my friend. And don't                          forget to jump. 1
35 The tent is full of commotion, soldiers and ministers com in and out. DoubleGreen- 22 July- p.102
Under whose orders is he acting?
He was told not to risk any more ships of the fleet. Elizabeth is distant from the general hubbub.

136 Raleigh at the helm of the Tyger gazing intently ahead. Before him, the might of the Spanish Armada. Behind him, men move down the ship with barrels, pouring pitch over t decks. Calley lights a torch and hands it to Raleigh. 137
Spanish sailors watch in horror as the spreading flames o the fire-ships move inexorably toward them.
138 A Spanish officer reacts to the danger and shouts command
(Raise anchor! Quickly! No - cut                          the ropes! Cut the ropes!)                                Ropes are slashed by flailing axes and cut away from the capstan.
139 Philip stares in horror at the flickering candle. The far off sound of the storm wind.
Elizabeth's entourage look at the maps stretched out on t tables. Hatton enters.
How many Spanish ships are burning? Hatton murmurs a figure. May 1 Blue Draft - p.103
Not enough. ON ELIZABETH- Staring out, as if to sea.
One empire will rise, and one will fall...

141 Raleigh on the prow of the Tyger as it sails towards the Spanish fleet. He holds a flaming torch, and calmly surve his target. He lights the fuses on the prow and tosses th torch behind him. The pitch on the deck bursts into flame He runs to the side of the ship and scales down the rigging. 1
42 Chaos and panic amongst the Spanish sailors as the fire- ship approaches. Men wildly fire off their muskets and th cannons boom.
143 Cannonballs crash into the side of the flaming Tyger. Certain now of the ship's course, Raleigh finally leaps into the water. As seen from underwater, Raleigh swims aw from the ship.
144 The prelaid fuses amongst the Tyger's cannons ignite, as the Tyger smashes into the side of the Spanish ship. From beneath, we see the hulls collide.
145 The Tyger's cannons explode causing devastation on the Spanish deck. Sailors run for cover. A horse rears and jumps over the side.
146 From underneath, men leap into the water. A horse swims past, lit from flames above. DoubleGoldenrod - 25 July -p.103A
John Dee stands on his roof, looking at the sky through a sextant.
Raleigh, singed and wet from his exploits, is with Drake the cabin.
How many ships are burning?
Four.
Not enough.                                            He turns his face towards the coast of England. He speaks as if to her, a quiet heart-felt prayer.
May God be with us all tonight. May 1 Blue Draft - p.104
147 The candle flickers. A clap of thunder, and the candle go out.

head_text.subj: EXT HILL ABOVE THE ENGLISH CAMP

text: Elizabeth looks out to sea. The wind roars, the clouds race, the lightning flashes.
148 Images of the beginning of the destruction of the Armada: Philip's portrait is covered by water inside a sinking cabin; a Madonna statue floats; a Spanish battle flag bur into flame.

151 Raging waves, black sea. The howl of the storm, the rendi of breaking timbers, the screams of drowning men. Somewhe out there, tiny in the vast seascape, the Armada is being smashed into oblivion.

head_text.subj: EXT HILL ABOVE THE ENGLISH CAMP- NIGHT

text: 152 Elizabeth stands there drinking in the tempest, the wind lashing her clothes and hair, but she loves it, lives it, breathes it. This is her storm - her victory.

153 The space that echoed before to the chants of war is sile now. Philip and the Infanta come down the nave. Philip's face set, expressionless. Philip reaches the steps at the foot of the altar. He goe down on his knees. Then he drops further down, to abase himself on the hard stone floor. The cardinals turn their backs to him.
he Infanta remains standing beside him, impassive, starin at nothing. She throws down her Elizabeth doll. May 1 Blue Draft - p.105
A low sob from Philip.

head_text.subj: EXT HILL ABOVE THE ENGLISH CAMP- NIGHT

text: Elizabeth triumphant in the roaring wind.
154 From inside a cave looking out to sea, a scene of devastation. Dead Spanish sailors have been washed up amongst planks, barrels and a torn Spanish ensign. A long scream of pain -
156 CLOSE ON BESS - Screaming in pain. A final spasm passes through her. She sinks back. The cry of a new-born child. She hears, and her exhausted face lights up with a radiant smile.
157 Walsingham lies in bed, his eyes closed. His wife Ursula and daughter Mary in the background. He's dying.
lizabeth has come to him. She looks down on him with deep concern.
Francis. My old friend.
158 An anonymous man - Agent 3 - walks down a shabby Paris street. Stops before a small anonymous house. Knocks.
159 The anonymous man is let into the house by a figure we don't yet see. He looks round the room. A fire burning in the grate. English books on the table. A half-eaten meal.
I come from your brother. Now we see who he speaks to: William. May 1 Blue Draft - p.106
What does he want?
He asks your forgiveness.
My forgiveness? On William: he stares. Then he understands. Fear brings sudden tears to his eyes. A gasp. Walsingham's man has plunged a knife into his heart.
160 Walsingham speaks to his Queen with difficulty.
I have served your majesty - in all things...
I know it, old friend. Don't leave me now. Walsingham's eyes open. A weak smile.
ou don't need me any more. Permission - to go - Elizabeth looks tenderly down on him, shaking her head.
You always did do as you pleased, whether I wanted it or not. I've no doubt you'll do as you please now. He lets his eyes close. She stoops down and kisses his cheek.
161 We see Raleigh from behind. He's holding something, and dancing slowly about, and crooning a low song, in the oddest way. Beyond him, half-glimpsed, an inner room, where Bess is resting on a bed.

Now in his solitary dance Raleigh turns, and we see he's holding a new-born BABY BOY. He kisses the baby's little bald head, and sings his wordless song. Footsteps outside. The door opens, and a royal servant enters, followed by other servants and guards.

Her majesty the Queen! Elizabeth enters, in formal style. She stands and takes i the scene - Raleigh holding his baby son - the room beyon Bess rises at once and comes through to make her curtsey the Queen. Elizabeth seems not to see her. A regal wave at the servants and guards. They withdraw. Elizabeth stalks round the room. No reason to suppose her displeasure has passed.
When was the birth?
our nights ago.
The mother is well?
Thank God. Now Elizabeth turns to Bess, and their eyes meet. The Que puts out her hand and touches Bess lightly on one cheek. silent forgiveness.
And the child?
My son is well. Now for the first time she looks at the baby.
Your Elizabeth has a child. You                        must be proud.
Yes. Elizabeth moves away, unable to bear seeing the baby.
And fulfilled?
As any man can be.                                 Elizabeth looks at him in silence for a long moment.
And do you still dream of your shining city, your New World?
More than ever.                                    She turns to go. But before she reaches the door, she stops.
I'd like to give your son my blessing.

I would be honoured. Elizabeth takes the baby in her arms. She holds him carefully. She finds herself more moved than she had expected. She bends her head over him, and turns her back on Raleigh. Raleigh watches and waits. And waits. ON ELIZABETH: her cheek pressed to the baby's head. Her eyes closed.

I am called the Virgin Queen. And yet I have many children... You are all my children. There is no                   jewel, be it never so rich a                       prize, which I put before this                     jewel: I mean, your love. I want                   no more wars. England is enough                    for me. I want no lordship over                    your souls. Only a free people                     can love.                                          (Beat)                                         And in your love - is my life.
